bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter and Laura Armistead Carter, November 21, 1904

div1.p: Carter discusses Henry Carter's academic progress and his plans to come home.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter and Laura Armistead Carter, November 21, 1904

opener.dateline:
U. S. PUBLIC HEALTH AND MARINE-HOSPITAL SERVICE,
OFFICE OF MEDICAL OFFICER IN COMMAND,
November 21,04 Ancon C.Z., 190

div1.p:
Well I found my letters at
the office this A.M. & a vessel leaves for
N.O. tomorrow noon - so by mail-
ing this at 6. A. M. You will get your
answers nearly as quick, as if I had
written them last night.

Yes I am glad that Laura got her
bracelet & necklace fixed, & if she can
get a proper “book-mark” she can have
her long-promised seal cut.

Henry finds his Anatomy hard. It is
hard, & very glad am I that Chemistry
is practically out of his way. I cannot
but congratulate myself on giving him
the smattering of chemistry - but a real
knowledge of its principles - with which
he went to College. It probably saved him
last year - for many a one failed in chemistry
- & succeeding last year is of infinite ad-
vantage to him this year.

He says that he is having a pleasanter time
than last year. Also that he is spending more
money- He says that all told it will cost him $500,
well. Henry is as far from extravagant as a fellow
well can be & I had rather he did not deny
himself what he wants - he will only want what
he ought to have.

I am utterly grieved about Dr Puriance- Officially
I had little use for him - personally I liked him.
He was always pleasant & I think was fond of me.

Have heard nothing from Probst - but ought to by
Sunday & if I hear anything by that time w'h
causes me to change my plan I will cable,
so no cable means no change- If I hear any-
thing by next Wednesday morning - making
me change my plan of leaving that day- 12 am
I will cable the next Saturday which you
will get before I could be there - “there” means
Baltimore-

I am very sorry to hear of Clarence's ill health. He is an
extremely pleasant fellow. There was more the mat-
ter with Carter than Finney found out - but still he had
nothing in the joint - that is good to know-
H. R C

My present plan is to bring my empty trunk
with me - so as to help bring things back but
things come far cheaper by freight than by
as baggage- The N.Y s.s. allows 200 lbs of
baggage on each ticket. I do not know when
the Spanish line allows. Freight to Pana-
way is $9 00/100 per ton $5 00/100 to Colon & $4 00/100 more to
Panama: & probably $2 00/100 to get it up the hill
in Carts.

If I am delayed would it not be well to
await me at N. R. I. Just as you all
choose. Lots of Malaria here, the Head Nurse
in dorm today & had to take Q. hyperdermat-
ically - as have a number of them. Practi-
cally all recover promptly, but get sick a-
gain. You may not think it but it is
to the full as hot as it was in July & 200%
wetter. I fear to risk you here
yet I judge that we will. There are
lots of privations however & few
compensations, still I am hoping
that this will be my last letter
until I see you again. Must close now
I have been hard at work all day arranging
for my Detention House, & will have everything as
well arranged as I can get it by Tuesday night,

Tomorrow is the “3d of November” & a holyday
of for all & a great fiesta- All of us are
going to hear the Te Deum, at 9 A. M. at
the Cathedral. I wish it were earlier say
7 or 7.30 when it was not so hot. How-
ever we are going-
div1.closer:
Your loving father
&
husband H. R. Carter I will mail this tonight - it is
about 9.45
